Description: Small Bes-jar, made of coarse red-brown siltware pottery, with drop-shaped body, flaring rim and lug-handles on either side of body. On the side, three very small spots of additional clay have been applied to represent the nose and eyes of the Bes-image. The rim is damaged. The fabric contains inclusions of stone, mostly limestone and chert grains.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 64, 65 § 61, pl. xxxv, 66)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.106, p.194, pl.36, p.218, pl.60)
